syllable.title: Korean Syllables
syllable.description: Discover how Korean syllables are built and understand the role of batchims (final consonants) and gyeobatchims (double final consonants).

chapters.title: Building a syllable
chapters.description: This chapter explains the basic rules for constructing a syllable block in Hangeul.
chapters.rulesTitle: Rules concerning the construction of syllables
rules: A syllable block is always made up of at least two letters (e.g. consonant + vowel).
Each syllable always starts with a consonant. If a syllable starts with a vowel, ieung (ㅇ) is used as a silent consonant.
A consonant is always followed by a vowel.
Each syllable block takes up the same square space to keep the writing balanced.
chapters.constructionDescription: Vertical vowels are written to the right of the consonant. Horizontal vowels are written below the consonant.

chapters.title: Batchims and Gyeobbatchims
chapters.description: This chapter introduces batchims (final consonants) and gyeobbatchims (double final consonants) with pronunciation rules and tips.
introTextParts: Final consonants in a syllable are called batchims and gyeobbatchims (겹받침 in Korean).
They are placed at the end of a syllable and have a pronunciation that differs from their initial position.
chapters.batchimText: Batchims (받침) are simple final consonants. Examples and pronunciation:
gyeobbatchimTextParts: In general, only the first consonant is pronounced.
Exceptions: ㄺ, ㄻ, ㄼ where the second consonant is pronounced.
chapters.liaisonTitle: Final consonants followed by a vowel
chapters.liaisonText: When a batchim or gyeobbatchim is followed by a syllable starting with a vowel, the final consonant sound links to the next syllable.
